bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to John H. Linson, May 30, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] informs Linson that Colon has established a full quarantine against several Colombian ports. [Carter] also reports on mosquito breeding in Puerto Rico. He believes that Puerto Rico needs more protection than the Canal Zone, which has a low Stegomyia index.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to John H. Linson, May 30, 1923
div1.opener:
Miss
Quarantine
Official
Columbia
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
May 30, 1923.
Surgeon John H. Linson,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Linson:
div1.p:
I suppose the Bureau has informed Fauntleroy at San Juan of the
fever at Bucaramanga, but if, by any chance, it has not I write this.

Russell tells me that Colon has put on a full quarantine against
Baranquilla (Puerto Colombia) and Cartagena and, since the Fruit Com-
pany complains, I presume on Santa Marta.

Now there is a fair chance of people from Bucaramanga going out
by Cúcuta and Maracaibo and thence by the Red D Line to Porto Rico:
probably not quite as much as by Colombian ports, but with this route
partially stopped it will turn such passenger traffic as there is out
through Maracaibo.

Cúcuta is now under investigation by Dr. White's party. It was supposed to have been
the source of the previous epidemic in Bucaramanga--getting its own
infection from Maracaibo. It is a coffee port with mainly German
buyers and the coffee formerly--and naturally--went out by Maracaibo.
It is in fairly low country and should be more exposed to yellow fever
than Bucaramanga. Yet It was regarded as an endemic centre of y. f. for
- say - 10 years before the World war

Unquestionably Fauntleroy should know all that we know of the
situation. He is an excellent Quarantine Officer, I expect, except
Grubbs, the best man we have for yellow fever, and I think he can
can
-2-
be trusted to take all the necessary measures to protect Porto Rico.
There is a hundred-fold more reason to protect that island than the
Canal Zone. In the latter the Stegomyia index is so low that yellow
fever would not spread anyway. Breeding is practically without con-
trol & w'd be difficult to control, in Porto Rico and within, it may be, fifty towns, and, as there
has been no fever there since the Spanish War, probably 65% or 70%
of the people are susceptible to it. Have held this 2 days awaiting news
from Cúcuta
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General.
